headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will c
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the Ross Stores Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2015 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Before we get started, on behalf of Ross Stores, I would like to note that the comments made on this call will contain forward-looking statements regarding expectations about future growth and financial results, including sales and earnings forecasts and other matters that are based on the company's current forecast of aspects of its future business. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from historical performance or current expectations. Risk factors are included in today's press release and the company's fiscal 2014 Form 10-K, Fiscal 2015 Form 10-Qs and 8-Ks on file with the SEC. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Barbara Rentler, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael Balmuth, Executive Chairman; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Joining me on our call today are Michael Balmuth, Executive Chairman; Michael O'Sullivan, President and Chief Operating Officer; Gary Cribb, Executive Vice President, Stores and Loss Prevention; John Call, Executive Vice President, Finance and Legal; Michael Hartshorn, Group Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Connie Kao, Senior Director of Investor Relations. 
We'll begin our call today with a review of our fourth quarter and 2015 performance, followed by our outlook for 2016. Afterwards, we'll be happy to respond to any questions you may have. 
As noted in today's press release, we are pleased with our sales and earnings results for the fourth quarter, which exceeded our expectations despite a highly promotional holiday selling environment. 
Additionally, we faced our most challenging sales comparisons from the prior year. Our results were driven by the competitive values we offered on a wide assortment of name-brand bargains and gifts throughout our store. 
Earnings per share for the fourth quarter grew 10% to $0.66 on net earnings that rose 6% to $264 million. 
Sales for the quarter increased 7% to $3,251,000,000, with comparable store sales up 4% on top of last year's 6% gain. 
For the 2015 fiscal year, earnings per share grew 14% to $2.51 on top of strong multi-year increases. Net earnings rose 10% to $1,021,000,000, with comparable sales up 4% for the year.
 dd's DISCOUNTS also posted better-than-expected gain in sales and operating profit for both the quarter and year. As customers continue to respond positively to their value offering. 
Sportswear was the best-performing merchandise category at Ross for the fourth quarter, while the Midwest was the strongest region. 
Our fourth quarter operating margin of 12.7% was down from last year as improved merchandise margins and strong expense control were more than offset by the timing of packaway-related costs. 
For the full year, however, we are pleased that operating margin increased 10 basis points to a record 13.6%. 
As we ended 2015, total consolidated inventories were up 3% over the prior year with packaway levels of 47% of total inventory compared to 45% last year. 
Average in-store inventories were down approximately 2% at year-end. 
During the fourth quarter, we repurchased 3.2 million shares of common stock for a total price of $170 million. 
For the full year, we repurchased 13.7 million shares for an aggregate price of $700 million. We expect to complete the $700 million remaining under our current 2-year, $1.4 billion program by the end of fiscal 2016. 
As noted in today's release, our board recently approved an increase in our quarterly cash dividend to $0.135 per share, up 15% on top of an 18% increase last year. The continued growth of our shareholder payouts reflects our ongoing confidence in the company's ability to generate significant amounts of cash after funding our growth and the other capital needs of our business. 
We have repurchased stock as planned every year since 1993 and raised our cash dividend annually since its inception in 1994. This consistent record reflects our unwavering commitment to enhancing stockholder value and return. 
Now Michael Hartshorn will provide further color on our 2015 results and details on our fiscal 2016 full year and first quarter guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with our fourth quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by a combination of higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. As Barbara mentioned, while full year operating margin w
componenttext:
Thank you, Barbara. Let's start with our fourth quarter results. Our 4% comparable store sales gain was driven by a combination of higher traffic and an increase in the size of the average basket. 
As Barbara mentioned, while full year operating margin was up 10 basis points compared to last year, fourth quarter operating margin declined 45 basis points to 12.7%. 
Cost of goods sold increased 75 basis points in the quarter, driven by 100 basis points of higher distribution expenses due to the timing of packaway-related costs that benefited earnings earlier in the year. Freight and buying expenses also rose 15 and 5 basis points, respectively. 
These increases were partially offset by merchandise margin improvement of 35 basis points from the prior year and 10 basis points of lower occupancy costs. Selling, general and administrative expenses during the period improved by 30 basis points, benefiting from strong cost control and leverage on the 4% comparable store sales increase. 
Our tax rate for the quarter was lower-than-expected due to the passage of federal tax credit legislation and also the favorable resolution of a state tax matter. 
Let's turn now to our guidance for the upcoming quarter and year. Earnings per share for fiscal 2016 are forecast to be in the range of $2.59 to $2.71, up 3% to 8% from $2.51 in fiscal 2015. 
The operating statement assumptions for fiscal 2016 include the following: Total sales are forecast to grow 4% to 5% on a comparable store sales increase of 1% to 2%. We expect to add about 70 Ross and 20 dd's DISCOUNTS locations. As usual, these numbers do not reflect our plans to close or relocate about 10 older stores. 
If same-store sales are in line with our guidance of up 1% to 2%, then we would project operating margin for 2016 to be 13.5% to 13.7%. This forecast calls for a slight increase in merchandise margin that would offset some deleveraging on operating costs. Net interest expense is estimated to be $17 million, our tax rate is projected to be approximately 37% to 38%. We expect average diluted shares outstanding to be about $395 million. 
Capital expenditures in 2016 are projected to be approximately $425 million, and depreciation and amortization expense inclusive of stock-based amortization is forecast to be about $385 million, up from $346 million in 2015. 
Lastly, our guidance includes our plans to raise the minimum wage for eligible hourly associates to $10 per hour in the second quarter of 2016, up from the current $9 minimum. 
These wage adjustments will help keep us competitive in our hiring practices and enhance our ability to retain talented associates to provide the shopping experience our customers have come to expect. 
Let's move now to our first quarter guidance. We are projecting same-store sales to be up 1% to 2% and earnings per share to be flat to up 4% at $0.69 to $0.72. 
Following are the assumption that support this range. Total sales are projected to increase 4% to 5%, we expect to open 22 new Ross and 6 dd's DISCOUNTS locations during the quarter. 
First quarter operating margin is projected to be 15.0% to 15.2% compared to last year's 15.7%. The forecasted decline is mainly from the timing of packaway-related costs that benefited the first quarter last year and also the impact of a new distribution center that opened in the second quarter of 2015. 
In addition, net interest expense for the quarter is estimated to be about $4.5 million, our tax rate is expected to be approximately 38% to 39%, and weighted average diluted shares outstanding are projected to be around 400 million. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Barbara for closing comments.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. We are very pleased with our strong performance in 2015 as we were, once again, are able to convert our better-than-expected revenue gains into solid double-digit earnings per share growth. These results are due to the resilience of ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. We are very pleased with our strong performance in 2015 as we were, once again, are able to convert our better-than-expected revenue gains into solid double-digit earnings per share growth. These results are due to the resilience of our off-price business model and our testament to the talented people we have throughout our organization. They have demonstrated, once again, their ability to deliver compelling bargains to our customers, which will always be the key to success in our business. 
As we move into 2016, we are well positioned to take advantage of the best opportunities in the marketplace. However, we continue to face our own challenging multi-year sales and earnings comparison. And with the increasing, uncertain and volatile macroeconomic climate, it doesn't appear that the retail landscape will get any less competitive or promotional in 2016. 
So while we hope to do better, we believe it's prudent to maintain a conservative posture when forecasting our business for this year. 
As we look ahead over the longer term, we remain confident in our ability to deliver average annual earnings per share gain in the low double-digit percentage range. This view is rooted in our belief that the off-price sector will remain a strong performing segment of retail, especially given consumers' ongoing focus on values. 
Equally important is our proven ability over time to maximize our favorable industry position by delivering the exceptional values our customers have come to expect. 
At this point, we'd like to open up the call and respond to any questions you might have.

componenttext: Yes, as we mentioned on the call Michael, it's Michael Hartshorn, for the quarter, it impacted us by about 100 basis points. And to walk through that timing of what happened during the year. Q1, we got about $0.03 benefit last year; Q3, we've got about $0.01 and then Q4 went $0.05 was a charge to earnings. So as we think about it going forward in the first quarter as we called out in our guidance, we expect some headwind in the first quarter. It's hard to predict how it will fall out during the rest of the year, and that's based on market availability of merchandise.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And it sounds like you're pleased with the inventory available in the channel, in the quarter as you head into the first half of the year. I'm trying to think about areas where you perhaps that will see -- as we walk around the stores here in the f
componenttext: Right. And it sounds like you're pleased with the inventory available in the channel, in the quarter as you head into the first half of the year. I'm trying to think about areas where you perhaps that will see -- as we walk around the stores here in the first quarter, where are some of the areas that we're going to see that you found to be more readily available perhaps than you thought as we get into the year?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, I think the availability, Michael, is pretty broad-based. I mean, it's really when you think about the sectors of the market where business was difficult, it's apparel, and it's home, so we feel that opportunity is in our business.
componenttext: Actually, I think the availability, Michael, is pretty broad-based. I mean, it's really when you think about the sectors of the market where business was difficult, it's apparel, and it's home, so we feel that opportunity is in our business.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just sneak in one final one, obviously, we get a lot of questions about new entrants coming into off price and everyone seems focused on getting their fair share of the growth that you talked about and the optimism you have in the cat
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just sneak in one final one, obviously, we get a lot of questions about new entrants coming into off price and everyone seems focused on getting their fair share of the growth that you talked about and the optimism you have in the category longer term. In the markets where you have seen rising count of competitors throw somehow into the off price umbrella, would you mind talking about sales dynamics, the competitive dynamics that you've seen in those markets?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Michael, it's Michael O'Sullivan. We really haven't seen an impact to this point to think about the signs of some of those new off-price entrants, just want to choose the pricing, that is too small to make much been impact. But I guess, I'd say m
componenttext: Sure. So Michael, it's Michael O'Sullivan. We really haven't seen an impact to this point to think about the signs of some of those new off-price entrants, just want to choose the pricing, that is too small to make much been impact. But I guess, I'd say more broadly, we tried to get too distracted by what other companies are doing, what new entrants coming into the market. We operate in a very competitive marketplace, and we try and focus on what we're good at and to make best use of the advantages and strength that we have. And as we look at the fourth quarter, the 4% comp on top of the 6% comp last year suggest that we're doing pretty well in that regard.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could -- you mentioned a promotional environment a few times in your prepared remarks. I was wondering if you could elaborate on a little bit. Are you seeing any impact on your customers or the marketplace given the broader more pro
componenttext: I was wondering if you could -- you mentioned a promotional environment a few times in your prepared remarks. I was wondering if you could elaborate on a little bit. Are you seeing any impact on your customers or the marketplace given the broader more promotional environment in the quarter? I mean obviously, really, they're really good comp, merchandise margins up. But how do you see that impacting the business? What are you concerned about how that might affect how consumer behavior, customers behave in in 2016?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the increased promotional environment, I think what we saw in the fourth quarter, especially in the department store sectors what we're going to see. As we continue through 2016. I, think what it means for the customers it means for us I mea
componenttext: Well, I think the increased promotional environment, I think what we saw in the fourth quarter, especially in the department store sectors what we're going to see. As we continue through 2016. I, think what it means for the customers it means for us I mean obviously we're not economist, so we can't determine what the customers are thinking. But I think what it means in our business is that we need to continue to deliver great value. And so value is something that moves based of what goes on in department stores and specialty stores. So we need to make sure that we do two things, and we stay very liquid so that we're there and can maximize on closed out opportunities, and those closed out opportunities then have to be at the right value. And since that moves, that gives us the flexibility to deliver the values that the customers are wanting.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But to be fair, it seems like, and tell me if I'm reading this wrong, it seems like thus far, your business is held up really well and haven't seen kind of any negative detrimental impacts from just how promotional was in the holiday quarter?
componenttext: Okay. But to be fair, it seems like, and tell me if I'm reading this wrong, it seems like thus far, your business is held up really well and haven't seen kind of any negative detrimental impacts from just how promotional was in the holiday quarter?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: While that's because we went into the quarter with two things. We then went in the quarter with very strong packaway values, and we also we, exceeded our sales expectations so we also chased a big part of that through closed out and the key to delivering
componenttext: While that's because we went into the quarter with two things. We then went in the quarter with very strong packaway values, and we also we, exceeded our sales expectations so we also chased a big part of that through closed out and the key to delivering value to the customers, understanding what goes around you. So you really had to serve make sure you keep that relationship so that the customer is satisfied.

componenttext: Appreciate all the color on the packaway and that seems to be the gift that's going to keep on giving as we go into 2016. Looking at the product in the warehouse, do you see more quarters or quarters that will be more impacted by packaway or less, let's say maybe you have gloves that will come out in November or swimsuits that will come out August? Any direction, is it evenly balanced on a quarterly basis or seasonal basis, I should say?

componenttext: Richard, I would say it's fairly evenly balanced. Nothing to call out on a quarter-by-quarter basis.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. And despite the environment and the competitive pressure we talked about earlier, looking into 2016, your caution remains. And is that the same old issues that say, we've talked about before, the competitive pressure department stores discounting? Or are there new things that are fueling your caution despite the high level of success in tremendous headwinds?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, I'd say it's partly a mix of new, partly mix of both things, but it sort of bubble up, I think, the 2 main factors. The first is the sort of the uncertainty in the macroeconomic and retail environment. And I know you heard us say that before, but
componenttext: Richard, I'd say it's partly a mix of new, partly mix of both things, but it sort of bubble up, I think, the 2 main factors. The first is the sort of the uncertainty in the macroeconomic and retail environment. And I know you heard us say that before, but this year, it seems to have gotten up and especially start in terms of the economy. So that's one thing to precaution. And then the other is our own top multi-year comparisons. Again, you haven't say that before, but again, if we just compare this coming quarter Q1 versus last year, we're up against a 5% comp. So again, we need to be cautious there in our guidance.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016

componenttext: On geographic performance, Bob, as we mentioned the Midwest continues to be our strongest region that's been true over the last 8 quarters. California, our largest region, also performed ahead of the chain average. I think you also asked about Texas, Texas was relatively in line with the chain on top of very strong comps last year when it was one of our top-performing regions.

componenttext: We do see in freight some cost increase, carry rate increases but it's just up slightly over 2015 is what we have planned.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So new store productivity in the quarter looks a little lighter than in the past where we've seen it. Can you just talk about performance in your latest store openings versus some of them are stores? Are there any timing shift which maybe could of impacte
componenttext: So new store productivity in the quarter looks a little lighter than in the past where we've seen it. Can you just talk about performance in your latest store openings versus some of them are stores? Are there any timing shift which maybe could of impacted this quarter? And just as a reminder, what comes to you guys see from new stores in the first 3 years versus the chain? And what's the average payback period?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Our new store productivity, there's nothing to talk about in the quarter. There's always a mix of whether you're opening new market stores or existing market stores. We have said in the past that the overall new store productivity has come down over
componenttext: Sure. Our new store productivity, there's nothing to talk about in the quarter. There's always a mix of whether you're opening new market stores or existing market stores. We have said in the past that the overall new store productivity has come down over the last couple of years with our entry into the Midwest and also our dd's expansion. That said, you can see the Midwest continues to be our strongest comping market as we continue to gain our name recognition there. What we usually see on the comp curve is over the first 5 years, we comp faster than the chain, and we settle in to about the chain average in year 5. Overall, we'll put about $1.5 million of capital and working capital to a store and the payback is about 2 years.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one quick follow up on that. When would you anticipate entering the Northeast?
componenttext: And then just one quick follow up on that. When would you anticipate entering the Northeast?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No further while. We entered the Midwest about 4 years ago now. And the Midwest is a fairly big region, so we feel like we've got plenty of opportunities to build out that region. That's probably going to keep us going certainly for the next few, the next
componenttext: No further while. We entered the Midwest about 4 years ago now. And the Midwest is a fairly big region, so we feel like we've got plenty of opportunities to build out that region. That's probably going to keep us going certainly for the next few, the next several years so it's going to be sometime before we enter the Northeast.

componenttext: Regarding the year ahead, as you are making these investments in labor, what are the major corporate strategies you're thinking about in terms of in-store execution opportunities with shrink or how you may think about the ratio of tops to bottoms or other opportunities like micro merchandising? And then I just had a question for modeling on the basket, can we assume that merch margin like AUR, was AUR as merch margins were up? I'm just curious about the dynamic there.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll start with the components of comp, Oliver. As we mentioned in our prepared remarks, the 4% comp was driven by a combination of higher transactions, which for us that's our proxy for traffic. And an increase in the size of the average basket. The h
componenttext: So I'll start with the components of comp, Oliver. As we mentioned in our prepared remarks, the 4% comp was driven by a combination of higher transactions, which for us that's our proxy for traffic. And an increase in the size of the average basket. The higher basket was driven both by higher units per transaction and AUR was up a bit as well. So all the components were up over last year, and that's pretty consistent with the trend we've seen throughout the year in 2015.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Oliver, as it pertains to top to bottom, we wouldn't talk about that in this form.
componenttext: And Oliver, as it pertains to top to bottom, we wouldn't talk about that in this form.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what about labor and how you're staffing stores? Any efficiencies that you can drive just as we think about incremental year-over-year opportunities? Because your execution has just been stellar, so if you're able to share with us any corporate
componenttext: Okay. And what about labor and how you're staffing stores? Any efficiencies that you can drive just as we think about incremental year-over-year opportunities? Because your execution has just been stellar, so if you're able to share with us any corporate strategy there, it would help us eliminate how we think about your numbers next year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Oliver, as Michael Hartshorn mentioned in the prepared remarks, we are going to be making further rate freight adjustments this year, including taking up the minimum hourly rate to $10 per eligible associates in the second quarter, and those cost
componenttext: Sure. So Oliver, as Michael Hartshorn mentioned in the prepared remarks, we are going to be making further rate freight adjustments this year, including taking up the minimum hourly rate to $10 per eligible associates in the second quarter, and those cost to be clear, built into our guidance. Now as we put together -- we have a very detailed and rigorous budgeting process as you might expect. And as we went through the budget for this year, we look to lots of different areas that we could go after to try and capture efficiencies and offset some of those increased expenses, increased wage expenses. There wasn't one big silver bullet, there were lots and lots of small saving initiatives that will add up to a lot, and it's all the things you should expect. Some of them, reengineering processes in the stores to better utilize labor hours. There's also things like looking for savings in terms of services and supplies that we purchase from the outside, looking for higher productivity in our DCs, looking for opportunities to trim non-merchant G&A. There are a whole bunch of, I would say, relatively small savings opportunities that add up to a lot and have allowed us to cover the freight rate increase that  Michael Hartshorn mentioned earlier.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just final the merch margins, it's great that you're making progress there. What's the rational for you being able to have that attractive view of merch margins going forward in the context of some of your conservatism about how the marketplace looks?
componenttext: And just final the merch margins, it's great that you're making progress there. What's the rational for you being able to have that attractive view of merch margins going forward in the context of some of your conservatism about how the marketplace looks?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start by talking about fourth quarter. So fourth quarter, we, obviously, outperformed the high end of our comp sales targets, so that meant we had faster inventory turns resulting in lower markdowns. We also benefited from our ability to take
componenttext: Well, let me start by talking about fourth quarter. So fourth quarter, we, obviously, outperformed the high end of our comp sales targets, so that meant we had faster inventory turns resulting in lower markdowns. We also benefited from our ability to take advantage of buying opportunities in the market place, so both of those factors really contributed to better-than-planned merchandise margin. And what we said in our guidance is we expect merchandise margins up slightly for the year. We did operate with lower inventories throughout 2015 and into the down 2% on an average store basis, and we expect to operate a bit low were in 2016 as well, and that should drive some margins improvements.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Brian Tunick from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Brian Tunick from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious, if you look at the merchandise mix of the business this past year and then you think 3 years from now, what do you think would be the biggest changes? Wouldn't be home growing faster than the rest of the business? Would it be gifts and beauty? Ju
componenttext: Curious, if you look at the merchandise mix of the business this past year and then you think 3 years from now, what do you think would be the biggest changes? Wouldn't be home growing faster than the rest of the business? Would it be gifts and beauty? Just curious of there's any categories you see moving over the next couple of years from where they are today. And then the second question, you're on new customer acquisition or your marketing initiatives. Anything you could share with us if you've done any work or studies over the last 12, 18 months about your sort of where your customers are coming from or what they're saying about Ross right now?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Brian, in terms of the merchandise mix, we basically see growth in all our areas. If I have to select one area, I would say probably Home would be that area. We've gone a lot of initiatives going on in there. And gift was a big portion of our fourth
componenttext: Okay. Brian, in terms of the merchandise mix, we basically see growth in all our areas. If I have to select one area, I would say probably Home would be that area. We've gone a lot of initiatives going on in there. And gift was a big portion of our fourth quarter success in Home this year, so if I would pick, it would be Home.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brian, your second piece about the customers and the new customers specifically, our new customers, frankly, looked a lot like our existing customers. We are -- as we do research on the demographics customers and what they're looking for, the new cust
componenttext: And Brian, your second piece about the customers and the new customers specifically, our new customers, frankly, looked a lot like our existing customers. We are -- as we do research on the demographics customers and what they're looking for, the new customers demographic, they're probably similar. What all our customers have in common no matter what the demographics is they're all looking for great value, great bargain. So in terms of making sure that we can attract more customers and retain customers, our main focus is having the best assortment we can, the best value that we can offer.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Glick from Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Glick from Buckingham Research.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to some of the differences that you were talking about between 2016 and 2015. One important difference seems like the department stores missed their plans by a much more significant margin in the fourth quarter assuming they're deep, a
componenttext: I wanted to go back to some of the differences that you were talking about between 2016 and 2015. One important difference seems like the department stores missed their plans by a much more significant margin in the fourth quarter assuming they're deep, a lot more packaway opportunity as a result. And there are all so pulling back more aggressively on their receipts that they plan for 2016. So does feel like they are being a little more conservative with their sales and receipt plans, particularly in the second half of this year. And I'm just wondering, how does that scenario play out for you guys? And what are the pluses and minuses given kind of what you see if I characterize it correctly what you see today?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, from the supply-side, department stores have pulled back over the last couple of years in total on how they plan. But it's not about how you plan it, it's really about the sales that materialize and the rate that you spend your receipt money. So as
componenttext: Well, from the supply-side, department stores have pulled back over the last couple of years in total on how they plan. But it's not about how you plan it, it's really about the sales that materialize and the rate that you spend your receipt money. So as you look at where the department stores ended in January, most of them ended with more inventory and clearly, ended with more clearance. And so as we enter into the spring season, one would expect that there would be a bubble of inventory that we would see in spring, which we could use to fuel in spring and back to your point on packaway that would help us drive through packaway. So it's relative to have department stores plan, it's relative to how the vendors plan with department stores and how much they're willing to pay. So we do feel there are -- there will be opportunities in the marketplace as long as traditional retailers continue to perform the way they're performing, you'll think that there'll be more opportunities there. So from that perspective on the supply-side, we feel good, which is why we're keeping ourselves liquid and see well positioned to take advantage of the opportunities in the marketplace.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if department stores inventories are more in line in the back half and I mean, they're always promotional obviously but if they're not in as much of the liquidation type scenario as they were in the fourth quarter of 2015, how does that impact your bu
componenttext: And if department stores inventories are more in line in the back half and I mean, they're always promotional obviously but if they're not in as much of the liquidation type scenario as they were in the fourth quarter of 2015, how does that impact your business? Is that an opportunity on the merchandise margin front? I'm just trying to think through what if that's potential opportunities as well.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just on the back to the supply line, sales are the key contributor to what happens of excess inventory. So sales are not stable in the world. The sales -- if you look at sales they been volatile, and you're watching department stores drop down. Second,
componenttext: So just on the back to the supply line, sales are the key contributor to what happens of excess inventory. So sales are not stable in the world. The sales -- if you look at sales they been volatile, and you're watching department stores drop down. Second, receipts versus sales are 2 different scenarios. That's what creates that bubble. In terms of margin, obviously, chasing closeouts and keeping tight inventory control helps us to get better position and improve our merchandise margin.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing I'd say, David, is when it's less promotional, clearly, we have more price differentiation we can offer better value. That tends to be better for us. But as you look at this year, certainly, the way this year has started, there are a l
componenttext: And the other thing I'd say, David, is when it's less promotional, clearly, we have more price differentiation we can offer better value. That tends to be better for us. But as you look at this year, certainly, the way this year has started, there are a lot of sort of economic uncertainty out there and who's to say whether or not a department  is going to hit their sales plans later this year or not anything can happen, which is why it makes sense for us to be relatively cautious as we plan our business for the year.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Marni Shapiro from The Retail Tracker.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I remember many, many years ago when off-price is to be the least respected space and now it's like the most coveted space out there. It's kind of nice. I guess, I have 2 quick questions on dd's. Suppose I wasn't sure, do you do packaway at dd's? And will
componenttext: I remember many, many years ago when off-price is to be the least respected space and now it's like the most coveted space out there. It's kind of nice. I guess, I have 2 quick questions on dd's. Suppose I wasn't sure, do you do packaway at dd's? And will you break out the percent if you do? And you have a new present in place in dd's and the business is doing well. I guess, you're opening about the same amount of stores each year. I guess, what do you need to see to take it to the next level of store openings at dd's?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So thank you for your respect, Marni.
componenttext: So thank you for your respect, Marni.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've always had my respect.
componenttext: You've always had my respect.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on dd's, a couple of quick answers to your three-part question. Yes, dd's does, indeed, use packaway and no we don't break it out just because dd's is about a small comp corporation, so we don't breakout, disclose that information. On the second part o
componenttext: So on dd's, a couple of quick answers to your three-part question. Yes, dd's does, indeed, use packaway and no we don't break it out just because dd's is about a small comp corporation, so we don't breakout, disclose that information. On the second part of your question what would we need to see, actually we're kind of already seeing it. We're pretty happy with dd's performance over the last several years. We kind of in the pattern here with dd's with better than expected gains in sales and profits over a few years now. So we opened just over 20 new dd's stores a year, which on a base of 170 stores, it's quite a bit growth rate. So I don't think you should expect that we're going to ramp that up significantly, maybe in a given year, it could go up to 25, but it's not going to increase dramatically. Our history, as you know, because you've been following us for a long time is that we're relatively conservative as we grow our businesses, as we've grown Ross, and we're applying the same thinking as we grow dd's. So the opening stores of 20 to 25 new stores is probably the right planning assumption.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That seems fair. And I guess on the same mind is growing the organization along with the stores, Ross always had many more buyers than your largest competitor for many years. You have an impressive merchandising staff considering the size of the store bas
componenttext: That seems fair. And I guess on the same mind is growing the organization along with the stores, Ross always had many more buyers than your largest competitor for many years. You have an impressive merchandising staff considering the size of the store base. How should I think about that at dd's? Has the merchandising staff and buying staff, is it much bigger relative to the size of dd's? Are you fully staffed there or is that still going to be a growing part of the business?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's very much the same model as you just described for Ross. We believe it fundamentally and off-price having the strongest buying team is a key competitive advantage and that applies to Ross and dd's. So dd's -- have we've invested in dd's buying team o
componenttext: It's very much the same model as you just described for Ross. We believe it fundamentally and off-price having the strongest buying team is a key competitive advantage and that applies to Ross and dd's. So dd's -- have we've invested in dd's buying team over the last several years, and we build a very strong asset there. I didn't really answer you asked a question earlier about Brian Morrow joining. I think it's hard [indiscernible] is also impacted, but I think that's what we've made.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Baker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Baker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to follow up real quickly on the wages issue, the move from $9 to $10. Could you quantify what kind of impact that will have on your total cost structure this year and how might that compare with any increases that you took in 2015?
componenttext: So I just wanted to follow up real quickly on the wages issue, the move from $9 to $10. Could you quantify what kind of impact that will have on your total cost structure this year and how might that compare with any increases that you took in 2015?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We didn't quantify the impact because what we said is we've been able to substantially mitigate those costs. As Michael O'Sullivan referred to before, that was very numerous cost efficiency projects than frankly no silver bullets. The savings came from a
componenttext: We didn't quantify the impact because what we said is we've been able to substantially mitigate those costs. As Michael O'Sullivan referred to before, that was very numerous cost efficiency projects than frankly no silver bullets. The savings came from a different projects across many areas of the business, non-payroll and payroll-related activities, so given that we've offset them in the guidance and offset them in 2015, we haven't quantified the impacts.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with all the offsets, a similar impact in '15 versus '16? In other words, impacts that you can manage to offset?
componenttext: So with all the offsets, a similar impact in '15 versus '16? In other words, impacts that you can manage to offset?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would say, remember, we went to $9 last year and $10 this year, so the impact is actually larger in '16 than it was in '15.
componenttext: Yes. And I would say, remember, we went to $9 last year and $10 this year, so the impact is actually larger in '16 than it was in '15.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: But still you're able to offset it?
componenttext: But still you're able to offset it?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike. [indiscernible]
componenttext: Yes, Mike. [indiscernible]

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Second -- okay, just another quick one. The earnings growth, how did it pace throughout the year? So we see the full year, we see the first quarter, so some quarter throughout the year is going to be have to be better than the first quarter with the wage
componenttext: Second -- okay, just another quick one. The earnings growth, how did it pace throughout the year? So we see the full year, we see the first quarter, so some quarter throughout the year is going to be have to be better than the first quarter with the wage increase coming in the second half of the year, I would think that, that would impact of that, but then again the packaway thing is reserving, so I guess, which quarter should be bigger than the others in terms of earnings grow?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we are not willing to give one quarter at the time. It's really going to be driven by sales. I mean, that's the impact, the biggest impact on earnings. But we wouldn't quantify the quarters until we get to the conference call previous to the quarter.
componenttext: So we are not willing to give one quarter at the time. It's really going to be driven by sales. I mean, that's the impact, the biggest impact on earnings. But we wouldn't quantify the quarters until we get to the conference call previous to the quarter.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. You're guiding to the same comp growth throughout the year, which is why I want to understand why the earnings growth would be different. But okay, I guess, we can figure that out in our own model.
componenttext: Understood. You're guiding to the same comp growth throughout the year, which is why I want to understand why the earnings growth would be different. But okay, I guess, we can figure that out in our own model.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure.
componenttext: Sure.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Mann from Johnson Rice.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question or couple of questions on the balance sheet. The inventory growth in the fourth quarter was only like 3%<, 3%, which was the slowest growth all year, which seems a little counterintuitive given the abundant availability merchandise I we're all he
componenttext: Question or couple of questions on the balance sheet. The inventory growth in the fourth quarter was only like 3%<, 3%, which was the slowest growth all year, which seems a little counterintuitive given the abundant availability merchandise I we're all hearing about because I'm curious if you can reconcile that the reason you weren't more aggressive with taking advantage of the availability or we see availability may be not as strong as we are all thinking?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, David, there's availability in the market. But as you're talking about buying packaway, there's few things involved with buying packaway. There is price, there is a value, there is the timing of delivery. So when we went in there and assess what we bo
componenttext: No, David, there's availability in the market. But as you're talking about buying packaway, there's few things involved with buying packaway. There is price, there is a value, there is the timing of delivery. So when we went in there and assess what we bought, we ended at 47% versus 45%, so we were comfortable with that number, and we'll continue to buy goods as we come across using the same criteria understanding where we believe value will go in the future.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other balance sheet item. The accounts payable leverage has been trending down all year. Even though you're obviously turning merchandise pretty fast. Michael, anything you can share on that about why that's going down and where we woul
componenttext: Okay. And then one other balance sheet item. The accounts payable leverage has been trending down all year. Even though you're obviously turning merchandise pretty fast. Michael, anything you can share on that about why that's going down and where we would think that would go perhaps in '16?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in '16, it will be similar levels to this year. At year-end, there was a timing difference. If you recall last year, we had the port disruption and as part of our mitigation efforts, we brought in inventory early that had a brought up leverag
componenttext: Yes, I think in '16, it will be similar levels to this year. At year-end, there was a timing difference. If you recall last year, we had the port disruption and as part of our mitigation efforts, we brought in inventory early that had a brought up leverage last year, so we were up against that compare. But really, it's a function of timing of receipts, including packaway receipts.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Barbara, I just wanted to follow up on David's question regarding the 3% growth in inventory in the fourth quarter. Would the right conclusion be -- based on the comments that you just made that your view of where the value or where there -- may be the ma
componenttext: Barbara, I just wanted to follow up on David's question regarding the 3% growth in inventory in the fourth quarter. Would the right conclusion be -- based on the comments that you just made that your view of where the value or where there -- may be the market price of goods is going in the short term might be down, and so you were basically holding back committing to packaway goods given your cautious outlook? And then, as a result of that, your view would then be you might be able to in fact buy even more goods end of February, March, even April time frame relative to those that you could acquire in November and December? Is that the right read on the situation?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the way I would look at the situation is whenever we buy packaway, whether it was this past fourth quarter, or any fourth quarter, those are the metrics we look at, price, value, timing of when we want to bring it in. So we're just going through t
componenttext: I think the way I would look at the situation is whenever we buy packaway, whether it was this past fourth quarter, or any fourth quarter, those are the metrics we look at, price, value, timing of when we want to bring it in. So we're just going through the same process we normally go through. So when we went out and there were goods available, we went to see if we thought it met the criteria where we thought we are going. And in some places, you're assuming that the vendors have merchandise they're going to move on the price, right? So sometimes, vendors move on the price based on their variance, it's the end of the quarter, it's the end of a half. So there's a lot of variables that we can't control. The only thing I can say is that we bought what we thought was appropriate. We ended with 47% versus 45%. We feel comfortable with that number and ultimately, we're only going to buy what we think is the right price. Your packaway is very hard to nail down in a quarter, in the POM, there has to be -- there is some our to buying packaway. You have to feel comfortable that after you put that in there, when you go to bring that out, whether it's 4 months later, 8 months later, 6 months later, depending on the product that the value is right. So there's a lot of variables that we can't determine as we're out in the marketplace, but that's really what the buyers do everyday of the week. So that was really our assessment in the fourth quarter of how we sell about packaway. Now whether vendors will move off the price as we get further into the next season, maybe, maybe some people will hold inventory over. I can't answer those question for the vendors. I can only answer what we feel comfortable in doing, which is same thing we've done every season.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one follow up to that. Do you -- the vendors in general seem to have a somewhat challenging 2015, including a tough Q4. Were you hearing from any of your vendors that they thought maybe there might be a change in strategy, opportunity in 2
componenttext: Great. And just one follow up to that. Do you -- the vendors in general seem to have a somewhat challenging 2015, including a tough Q4. Were you hearing from any of your vendors that they thought maybe there might be a change in strategy, opportunity in 2016 or a different way to approach their own inventory management? Or do they reveal that information to you? And do you have any color on perhaps what may be happening broadly among the vendor community that you might be able to share in this form?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Not really, Kimberly. I mean vendors aren't going to be quick telling us they're going to have more or less inventory. So it's really -- each vendor does their own thing, and so I can't really determine that, to be honest with you.
componenttext: Yes. Not really, Kimberly. I mean vendors aren't going to be quick telling us they're going to have more or less inventory. So it's really -- each vendor does their own thing, and so I can't really determine that, to be honest with you.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Hofkin from William Blair & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Hofkin from William Blair & Company.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. So thinking about beyond, and I know you haven't giving guidance for next year yet, is it fair to say that you would likely expect to further wage increases beyond this year similar to what your largest competitor has dis
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. So thinking about beyond, and I know you haven't giving guidance for next year yet, is it fair to say that you would likely expect to further wage increases beyond this year similar to what your largest competitor has discussed? And I guess, related to that, what enables you beyond this year to kind of get to the low double digits, sort of normalized EPS growth given that this year's increases that you're offsetting them in a number of ways on SG&A. And then I have one follow up.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Daniel, as you say, next year, no, we haven't released guidance for 2017 yet. But I think we've said before that we would expect that over the next few years if the economy or if the economy picks up, that we may see more expense pressures not the staf
componenttext: So Daniel, as you say, next year, no, we haven't released guidance for 2017 yet. But I think we've said before that we would expect that over the next few years if the economy or if the economy picks up, that we may see more expense pressures not the staff, but in general, companies and retailers will face more expense pressures, including higher wage rates. Obviously, as we start to plan 2017, which wouldn't be for some time, but as we start to plan for 2017, we'll start to look at one of the kinds of things that we can put in place to offset those kinds of expense pressures. Too early to comment on this now, but that will be the kind of process that we would go through.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, is there just big picture thing in terms of like that allows you to get to more normalized low double-digit EPS growth over time?
componenttext: Okay, is there just big picture thing in terms of like that allows you to get to more normalized low double-digit EPS growth over time?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just to be clear, I mean, we ended the year with EPS up 14% despite the wage increase on the 4 comps. And certainly, in between a 3 and 4 comp, we think we can get to double-digit EPS growth over the longer term.
componenttext: Well, just to be clear, I mean, we ended the year with EPS up 14% despite the wage increase on the 4 comps. And certainly, in between a 3 and 4 comp, we think we can get to double-digit EPS growth over the longer term.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's worth underlining that point. Our guidance this year is obviously 1% to 2% comp and that's what's driving the EPS guidance. As what Michael Hartshorn just said, in a more normalized comp, I think we've said in the past that our long term model includ
componenttext: It's worth underlining that point. Our guidance this year is obviously 1% to 2% comp and that's what's driving the EPS guidance. As what Michael Hartshorn just said, in a more normalized comp, I think we've said in the past that our long term model includes a 3% to 4%, comp. At those levels, we expect low double-digit EPS growth.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then as it relates to AUR in a slightly different trend for you versus the main competitor, any comment there in terms of what -- I know presumably net inflation, there's probably some mix there, but what's driving the moderately highe
componenttext: That's helpful. And then as it relates to AUR in a slightly different trend for you versus the main competitor, any comment there in terms of what -- I know presumably net inflation, there's probably some mix there, but what's driving the moderately higher AUR for you guys versus the other company?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean for us it's a bit of mix, but also we continue to operate with lower end inventory levels, which means we're  taking markdowns, we're turning faster, and it has an impact on AUR on higher prices. I'd say so between those 2 mix and our lower ma
componenttext: Yes, I mean for us it's a bit of mix, but also we continue to operate with lower end inventory levels, which means we're  taking markdowns, we're turning faster, and it has an impact on AUR on higher prices. I'd say so between those 2 mix and our lower markdowns is what's driving higher AUR.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Lejuez from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Lejuez from Citi.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, just wondering as far as CapEx once we look beyond this year, is there anything lumpy we need to be thinking about over the next several years? It might be on your radar screen that you can share with us. And also just thinking about some of the --
componenttext: Guys, just wondering as far as CapEx once we look beyond this year, is there anything lumpy we need to be thinking about over the next several years? It might be on your radar screen that you can share with us. And also just thinking about some of the -- where are your customers cross shopping? Which retailers do you see the most overlap with? And curious if you look at when you see big box department store retailer close, what sort of a lift do you get in your buy stores if, in fact, you take a look at that?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, on capital, at least over the next couple of years, it looked very similar to what we said for 2016. Call it for 4 25 to 4 50 range. So nothing extraordinary currently in the longer -- at least over the next couple of years.
componenttext: Paul, on capital, at least over the next couple of years, it looked very similar to what we said for 2016. Call it for 4 25 to 4 50 range. So nothing extraordinary currently in the longer -- at least over the next couple of years.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Paul, on the other 2 pieces of your questions, our customers, we operate in a very pretty large and very competitively fragmented marketplace. So when we ask our customers if you haven't spend that $30 at Ross today, where would you spend it? We get a
componenttext: And Paul, on the other 2 pieces of your questions, our customers, we operate in a very pretty large and very competitively fragmented marketplace. So when we ask our customers if you haven't spend that $30 at Ross today, where would you spend it? We get a long list of companies that they would have spend that money at. So from cross shopping point of view, we're competing with everyone, which is why we need to make sure we have the best value out there. In terms of your...

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anything that would top that list?
componenttext: Anything that would top that list?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It depends on the particular store, the particular market that we're looking at. Nationally, I think you could probably just pick apples and peers and nationally, obviously, they would show up on that list. But the point I'm trying to make is none of them
componenttext: It depends on the particular store, the particular market that we're looking at. Nationally, I think you could probably just pick apples and peers and nationally, obviously, they would show up on that list. But the point I'm trying to make is none of them account for a very large share count as compare to the list itself,  it's very fragmented and spread between many, many competitors, which is why we need to make sure that we shop with our competitors. The last part of your question though big-box department  stores and how that affects any of our individual stores. It's really hard to say because the truth is there are a lot of things that go into the business that an individual store does, including traffic levels to that strip mall, the competitive intensity in that strip mall. Sometimes actually having more off-price and that's actually be helpful. So it's hard to say whether or not a large retailer buy going out of business help us, will hurt us. It depends on who replaces in that place, what will happen to the traffic in that level in that strip mall, et cetera.

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Just one more. Any changes in your store sizes for your openings next year as you manage inventories down? Just wondering if you continue to bring the size of the stores down.

componenttext: Sure. So the time that we brought on our average inventory per store by about 40% over the last several years has presented us with a few opportunities to make the stores easier to shop, so we've certainly been doing that, expand into faster-growing or new categories, again, we've been doing that. And then as you're referencing also to reduce the store size, obviously, that's feasible for new store rather than existing stores, but we've also been doing that to some degree as well. So I would say that the lower inventory levels are given us doing a number of things with regard to the size of the store and how we use the space in the store.

componenttext: Just wanted to make sure I'm clear on the gross margin of packaway topic. This was one of the biggest swings as it relates to the impact on both of these in years. So can you just clarify some of the drivers of these factors given the absolute percentage of packaway didn't seem to move much?

headline: Ross Stores Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the absolute dollars of packaway did drop during the quarter, Stephen. So as we've talked about in the past, we capitalized the cost the store and process packaway, including fixed costs. And for us, we charge gross margin or charge cost of goods sold
componenttext: So the absolute dollars of packaway did drop during the quarter, Stephen. So as we've talked about in the past, we capitalized the cost the store and process packaway, including fixed costs. And for us, we charge gross margin or charge cost of goods sold when it's sells. So for us, the absolute dollar value of packaway fell during the quarter, which means we had to take a charge and that was greater than the previous year. Of the 100 basis points of distribution center deleverage in the quarter, all of that was related to the packaway time.

componenttext: Sure. So we don't have any plans right now to launch a loyalty program. We're always willing to look at new ideas. But frankly over time, we've had the most effective way to build customer loyalty with the off-price customer is to consistently offer great deals, great bargains. So more than anything that's how we build loyalty.
